channel.title: The Subbuteo Argus
channel.description: The Subbuteo Argus is a weekly table football newsletter, covering table soccer news from FISTF-affiliated and WASPA-affiliated national associations.

item.title: Scottish Cup joy for Christie
item.description:
Headlines

Christie lifts Scottish Cup

There was joy in Burntisland for Dundee United player Gareth Christie last weekend, as he beat Manchester TFC’s Malcolm Lees 2-0 in the final to lift the Scottish Cup, having defeated Andy Beskaby in the semi-finals. Lees himself had overcome strong opposition in the form of Dundee United’s Greg Dand and Glasgow’s Tom Burns, but fell short at the final hurdle.

Articles

  • How Subbuteo was introduced to Portugal [pt] (Google translate)
  • Juan Carlos Granados: Creator of Champions [it] (Google translate)
  • Video from the team final of the German GP
  • The return of Subbuteo Rugby [it] (Google translate)

FISTF World Cup 2015

  • Gala dinner announced
  • Full entry list revealed [es] (Google translate)
  • Maintaining World Class pitches [it] (Google translate)

The Argus: Volume 14

Volume 13 of The Argus will draw to a close at the end of this month, making way for the imaginatively titled ‘Volume 14’.

You may have noticed that there’s been a few interviews, and other articles, appearing over the past few weeks. The plan, along with a few visual tweaks to the design, is to include more articles in the newsletter:- expect features on the return of the Scottish national team to the World Cup, the Italian Club League, and an opinion piece on the future of the game in the UK to appear early on.

If you have any ideas for topics that could be covered, feel that you could provide an insight in to the game through an interview, have some news but nowhere to publish it, or would like to contribute a piece yourself, please get in touch by replying to this email. Anything Subbuteo-related will be considered!

item.title: Black & Blue Treble at Mattersburg Major
item.description:
Headlines

Victory for Pisa in Mattersburg Major

Black & Blue Pisa have continued their stellar season by lifting the team trophy, beating Fiamme Azzurre Roma 8-5 on goals scored in the final. The individual competition yielded another success for the Tuscans, with Daniele Bertelli defeating Catania IO winner Luca Colangelo 2-1 in the final, having defeated world champion Juan Noguera by the same score at the semi-final stage. Pisa also saw success in the veteran category, with Mauro Manganello taking the title. Google translate version

Articles

  • Video from the final of the German GP
  • LEGOalkeeper - make your own training aid out of Lego

FISTF World Cup 2015

  • Brazil names two man World Cup squad
  • Beer glasses added to array of World Cup merchandise [it] (Google translate)

Talking To Walker

This weekend, Zach Walker will attempt to equal Gregg Deinhart’s record of seven US National Championship titles, won between 1996 and 2004. Despite his impressive record, however, Walker feels that he’ll have his work cut out. He names US World Cup squad members Paul O’Donovan Rossa and Peter Alegi, former U19 champions Michael Tillman (2012) and Stuart Russell (2011), and home players Ilias Gikas and Erik Haefke amongst the strongest of the competition. And that’s before you get on to former national champions Daniel Cranston (2009, 2011) and Paul Eyes (2012)!

For a player who has seen so many top tournaments, you have to wonder which stick out as being the most memorable. “Certainly have been several”, comes the reply from the man from Colorado. It’s telling that, amongst the list of European Majors and FISTF World Cups come three tournaments closer to home; the 1999 and 2006 ASA National Championships, and the 2007 ASA Holiday Silver - the largest tournament ever held on American soil, attracting 66 players.

So what has he learnt in his 16 years at the top of the game? “Smile more while playing. I think you have to be serious and intense in this game in order to succeed, but having fun is the most important part”. Surely good advice for every player.

item.title: Mattersburg players dominate in German GP
item.description:
Headlines

Leitner takes honours in Bavaria

TFC Mattersburg’s Wolfgang Leitner won the German GP in Rain last weekend, defeating fellow Austrian Alexander Haas. The club also lifted the team trophy, comfortably beating Belgian side SC Stembert in the final, having dispatched fellow Austrians Wiener Neustadt at the semi-final stage. In the categories, World number 1 Gianfranco Calonico (Italy) won the veteran category, with Austrian youngsters Lukas Eppensteiner (Under 15) and Daniel Vranovitz (Under 12) won the junior categories, and home player Arnold Mair came out on top in the plate competition. Google translate version of main report

Excellent English GP for AS Hennuyer

75 players attended what must be seen as a warm-up for the FISTF Major to be held in England in 2016, with Belgian Under 19 star David Vantassel beating French AS Hennuyer teammate Remi Soret 2-1 after extra time in the final. With the veteran Belgian club providing both Open finalists, there was little shock when they also lifted the team competition, beating London & Essex United 3-1 in the final.

  • Japanese IO victory for Cédric Garnier
  • Loureiro is the toast of Porto

Articles

  • “Where are we playing?”: Australia’s first inter-club tournament
  • Nominations for 2015 FISTF Awards announced
  • Minutes from the French association’s AGM [fr] (Google translate)

ASA National Championships

This year sees the 25th anniversary of the American association’s national championships, to be hosted in Chicago on 8th/9th August. The first championships were first played in 1982, becoming an annual event ten years later. Some readers with longer memories might remember the last official “Subbuteo” World Cup - run by Waddingtons in 1994 - was held in the city, Belgian player Dominique De Marco defeating France’s Christophe Fuseau 4-3 in the final.

The tournament is to be hosted by Chicago United TSC, which has grown to become one of the largest clubs in the United States since the merger of Midwest United SC and the Chicago Area SC last December. Zach Walker will face stiff competition as he looks to equal Gregg Deinhart’s record 7 titles at the event. A short interview with the former English Premier League player will follow next week.

item.title: Hitting the Sweet spot
item.description:
Hitting the Sweet spot

Part of a delegation of 8 players from the USA going to Italy for the World Cup this September represents the culmination of a Subbuteo career lasting for 42 years - with a large break in the middle - for incoming ASA president Chris Sweetland.

A childhood friend who had returned to the Chicago from London brought the game back with him. The pair played for hours every day, playing by an improvised set of rules, isolated from the rest of the community. “We were the only two players we were aware of in the area.”, says Chris, “We were really not too aware of what was going on with the game in the United States or internationally, and we really did not care.” The pair maintained detailed statistics on every figure in on their team, publishing a sports paper with colourful match reports.

Several years passed, by which time they had subscribed to a Subbuteo newsletter, becoming aware of the popularity of the game overseas, although they were unaware of anyone else in the area that played. Then, after graduating from high school, Chris left for college, with the intention of finishing his involvement with the game. “We would get together occasionally and I would play with my two brothers but I put the game away for what I thought was forever when I graduated high school”.

Then, two years ago, Chris returned. “I knocked around for about 2 months before deciding to search the game on-line to find out what had become of it”, he says. “I was almost sure, at the time, that the game had died a slow death.”. Instead he found that not only was the same still going, but there was some relatively local action too, with a group of players a three hour drive away, in Michigan. There were also small groups throughout the country, each with similar stories to his their own.

In a typically upbeat statement, Chris describes how the Chicago club that he’d founded has blossomed: “Our club decided to host the 2015 ASA National Tournament in August as a way to gain national visibility as a club that wants to see the sport grow”. Within months he had become an active organiser in the Midwest, becoming ASA Vice President for the region. He is due to become ASA President in September this year.

He’s very positive, too, about the benefits that Twitter, Facebook, and internet forums can bring: “Social media has been really good for the game. It allows us to see what is happening around the world in real-time. It really helped promote and keep the game vibrant in the United States as well since there is such a large geographic divide between the active pockets of Subbuteo players”. He also sees this as the future of the American game, providing a way to bring younger players in to an association with an ageing membership.

He’s no less enthusiastic about the role that FISTF, WASPA and the American Subbuteo Association have played, continuing “I liked the fact that a broadly accepted set of rule changes came out of this effort [by FISTF] recently many of which I think add to the enjoyment and playability of the game.”

Whilst Chris classes himself as one of the less-abled players on the American circuit, he feels that he has become far more competitive since his return. “I refer to it more often these days as a sport rather than as a game.”, he says, “It encompasses real head to head heartfelt competition and thoughtful strategy. Don’t get me wrong, I always enjoyed scoring the winning goal against my childhood buddy, but, today it feels more like the competition I enjoyed in my college American football and baseball days.”

“What struck me when I was reintroducing myself to the sport and travelling throughout the Midwest was how much I enjoyed the people and the camaraderie they promote. People here really enjoy being with each other at these tournament gatherings and want to see the sport grow. I would liken many of these gatherings to those long weekends we sometimes have with buddies from our high school and college days who long since moved away.”

Finally, where will the game be in 30 years time? Chris is positive: “I actually think that it will grow as long as there is a continuing strong interest in football world-wide.” The link with football is key, Chris feels, along with an active recruitment effort for younger players via social media and on the ground by local clubs.

item.title: Eagles lose fight for Di Vito
item.description:
Headlines

Eagles Napoli lose the fight for Di Vito

Italian starlet Marco Di Vito has made a cross-city move from Eagles Napoli to rivals Fighters Napoli. Having been part of Eagles’ Europa Cup for Clubs-winning side, and schooled by Massimo Bolognino and Massimiliano Nastasi, the move comes as quite a coup for Fighters. Google translate version

item.title: Falcons soar in Athens Major
item.description:
Headlines

Falcons soar in Athens Major

Athens Falcons stormed to victory amongst a field of a Greek record 22 teams, beating Olympia in the final of the team event to lift the title. Meanwhile, Spryos Hantzaras won the open category, defeating local legend George Koutis 1-0 in the final. Edoardo Bellotto (Veterans), Elodie Bertholet (Female), Nicolo Borgo (U19), and Marcos Falelakis (U12) also took home silverware.

Sensational victory for Luca Colangelo at IO Catania

1-0 down with five minutes to go against Malta’s Hansel Mallia, Italian youngster struck twice to win the IO Catania. Fiamme Azzurre Roma won the team event, beating the home side 3-1 in the final. Google translate version

Victory for Prats in Barcelona

Last weekend saw Vicenç Prats take the historic Barcelona IO title, defeating Ferran Coli 2-1 in the final. However, he failed to make it a double, losing by a single goal to Antonio Montaño in the veterans category.

item.title: Tayside IO victory for Bennett
item.description:
Headlines

Home win for Bennett in Tayside IO

Local player Steve Bennett defeated England’s Trevor Schott in the final of the Interntational Open of Tayside to add another Scottish title to his expanding collection. Bennett picked up further honours in the following day, with his club - Dundee United TFC - taking home the team trophy.

item.title: Soret and Murcilli sweep up honours
item.description:
Headlines

Full honours for Claudio Murcilli in Rosario

Claudio Murcilli struck twice to lift both the Open and Veteran category titles in the International Open of Argentina in Rosario, beating Fabrizio Bertolini on both occasions.

Remi Soret wins Championnats de France

Remi Soret walked to victory in the French national championships last weekend, topping the first division ahead of Jean-Marie Amberny and Axel Donval having won every game. Meanwhile, FTC Issy-les-Moulineaux won the team championship, having also won every match, with FTC Puylaurens in second position. Bretagne won the regional category, with Pays de Loire in second place and France Mixte in third.

Double vision for Martinelli at English Satellite weekender

Luca Martinelli beat Cypriot Paul Andreas 3-1 on Saturday, then defeated Colin Tarry 4-1 on Sunday, to take both open category titles in the English Satellite weekender in Enderby, near Leicester, last weekend. The veterans category say Justin Finch beat Jeremy Bradley 5-0 on the opening day, whilst Dave Pawsey beat Brian Daley 3-1 in Sunday’s competition.

item.title: Great strides forward for Italy, USA and Singapore
item.description:
Headlines

Results from the Bologna Major released

Bologna Tigers, still going strong in their 40th year, have released the results from the Major, along with a full report being published by ItaliaSubbuteo.

Singapore getting set for International Open

Indicative of the surge in popularity for the game in the far east, the governing body of the game in Singapore expect 38 players from seven nations - Singapore, Japan, Australia, Italy, France, Belgium, and Malaysia - to compete in it’s International Open this weekend. Alongside the usual category games will be international friendlies in both Open and U15 categories between Singpore and Japan.

USA Announces World Cup Squad

The USA has announced that it will send a record 8 players to the FISTF World Cup this season, including teams in both the open and veteran categories. Captained by Zach Walker, the squad also includes former England Champion Paul O’Donovan Rossa.
